qas.question: what is the name of the movement of liberalism?
what sometimes prefers a more lenient position on Dietray laws?
previous generations typically praciced a more lenient position in regard to what?
What are dietary laws known as?
What has not been challenged by scholars?

plausible_answers.text: began to embrace far more stringent halachic practices

qas.question: What happened as a reaction to the conservatism movement?
What is not a religious requirement regarding dietary laws?
What explicitly prefers a more stricter position regarding Passover dietary laws?

context: However, the Orthodox claim to <b4_0>absolute fidelity<b4_0/> to past tradition has been challenged by scholars who contend that the <b5_0>Judaism<b5_0/> of the Middle Ages bore little resemblance to that practiced by today's Orthodox. Rather, the Orthodox community, as a counterreaction to the liberalism of the <a0_0>Haskalah<a0_0/> movement, <b6_0>began to embrace far more stringent <a3_0>halachic practices<b6_0/><a3_0/> than their predecessors, most notably in matters of Kashrut and Passover <a2_0>dietary laws<a2_0/>, where the <b7_0>strictest possible interpretation<b7_0/> becomes a religious requirement, even where the <a1_0><b8_0>Talmud<b8_0/><a1_0/> explicitly prefers a more lenient position, and even where a more lenient position was practiced by prior generations.
